div.l: The Folk gan lawhen at his fantasie
And to the roof þei kiken and thei cape
And turned all his arme vnto a iape
For what so this Carpenter answerde
It was for noght no man his resoıı̄un herde
He was anon right boren doıı̄un
That he was holden wood in all þe toıı̄un
For euꝰery clerk anon right helde with oþer
The seide the man is wood my leue brother
And euꝰery wight gan lawhen at þis stryf
Thus swyued was the Carpunters wyf
For al his kepyng and his Ialousie
And Absolon hath kessid hir nether eyghe
And Nicholas is scalded in his toute
This tale is doon and god saue all the route
Here endith the Milleres tale
And here byginneth þe prologe of the Reue
Whan folk han lawhen at this nyce caas
Of Absolon and hende Nicholas
Diuerse folk diủersely thei seide
But for the more part þei lowh ⁊and pleide
Ne at this tale I sawh no man him greue
But it were only Oswolde the reue
By cause he was of Carpiniters craft
A litel Ire in his herte laft
He gan to grucche ⁊and blamed it a lite
So theek quod he ful wel couthe I ȝow quite
With bleryng of a proude melleres eyghe
If þat me lyst to speke of ribaudie
But yk am olde me lyste not pleie forage
Gras tyme is done my foder is forage
This white top writeth myn olde ȝeres
Myn herte is also mouled as myn heres
But if I fare as doth an open ers
That ilke fruyt is euer lenger the wers
Till it be roten in Mullok or in stree
We olde men I drede so fare we
Til we be roten can we not be ripe
